notes.short: Send messages, receive commands, and work with device twins in Azure IoT Hub.

packets.name: instance_name
packets.description:
A friendly name that describes the role of this service instance in the device.
It often corresponds to what's printed on the device:
for example, `A` for button A, or `S0` for servo channel 0.
Words like `left` should be avoided because of localization issues (unless they are printed on the device).

packets.name: status_code
packets.description:
Reports the current state or error status of the device. ``code`` is a standardized value from 
the Jacdac status/error codes. ``vendor_code`` is any vendor specific error code describing the device
state. This report is typically not queried, when a device has an error, it will typically
add this report in frame along with the announce packet. If a service implements this register,
it should also support the ``status_code_changed`` event defined below.

packets.name: status_code_changed
packets.description: Notifies that the status code of the service changed.

packets.name: connect
packets.description:
Try connecting using currently set `connection_string`.
The service normally preiodically tries to connect automatically.

packets.name: disconnect
packets.description:
Disconnect from current Hub if any.
This disables auto-connect behavior, until a `connect` command is issued.

packets.name: send_string_msg
packets.description: Sends a short message in string format (it's typically JSON-encoded). Multiple properties can be attached.

packets.name: send_string_msg
packets.description: Sends a short message in string format (it's typically JSON-encoded). Multiple properties can be attached.

packets.name: send_msg_ext
packets.description: Sends an arbitrary, possibly binary, message. The size is only limited by RAM on the module.

packets.name: send_msg_ext
packets.description: Sends an arbitrary, possibly binary, message. The size is only limited by RAM on the module.

packets.name: message
packets.description: Part of the body of the message.

packets.name: properties
packets.description: Set properties on the message. Can be repeated multiple times.

packets.name: subscribe
packets.description: Subscribes for cloud to device messages, which will be sent over the specified pipe.

packets.name: devicebound_properties
packets.description:
If there are any properties, this meta-report is send one or more times.
All properties of a given message are always sent before the body.

packets.name: devicebound
packets.description: For every message, the body is sent in one or more reports like this.

packets.name: get_twin
packets.description: Ask for current device digital twin.

packets.name: twin_json
packets.description:
The JSON-encoded twin. This is typically something like:
`{ "desired": { "foo": 1, "$version": 12 }, "reported": { "foo": 1, "bar" 2, "$version": 123 } }`

packets.name: twin_error
packets.description: This emitted if status is not 200.

packets.name: subscribe_twin
packets.description: Subscribe to updates to our twin.

packets.name: twin_update_json
packets.description:
First, the current value of the twin is sent (this includes desired and reported properties).
Next updates done by the back-end are streamed as they arrive (they only include the desired properties).

packets.name: patch_twin
packets.description: Start twin update.

packets.name: patch_twin
packets.description: Start twin update.

packets.name: twin_patch_json
packets.description:
The JSON-encoded twin update. The pipe should be closed when the last packet is sent.
You just send updates for `reported` field, like this:
`{ "bar": 3, "baz": null }` (skip `"$version"` and no `"reported": { ... }`).

packets.name: subscribe_method
packets.description: Subscribe to direct method calls.

packets.name: method_call_body
packets.description:
The method call body is sent using these packets.
If the body is empty, a single empty `method_call_body` is sent.

packets.name: method_call
packets.description: This is sent after the last part of the `method_call_body`.

packets.name: respond_to_method
packets.description: Respond to a direct method call (`request_id` comes from `subscribe_method` pipe).

packets.name: respond_to_method
packets.description: Respond to a direct method call (`request_id` comes from `subscribe_method` pipe).

packets.name: method_response
packets.description: The pipe should be closed when the last packet of response body is sent.

packets.name: connection_status
packets.description: Returns `"ok"` when connected, and an error description otherwise.

packets.name: connection_string
packets.description:
Connection string typically looks something like 
`HostName=my-iot-hub.azure-devices.net;DeviceId=my-dev-007;SharedAccessKey=xyz+base64key`.
You can get it in `Shared access policies -> iothubowner -> Connection string-primary key` in the Azure Portal.
This register is write-only.
You can use `hub_name` and `device_id` to check if connection string is set, but you cannot get the shared access key.

packets.name: hub_name
packets.description: Something like `my-iot-hub.azure-devices.net`; empty string when `connection_string` is not set.

packets.name: device_id
packets.description: Something like `my-dev-007`; empty string when `connection_string` is not set.

packets.name: connected
packets.description: Emitted upon successful connection.

packets.name: connection_error
packets.description: Emitted when connection was lost.

packets.name: devicebound_str
packets.description:
This event is emitted upon reception of a cloud to device message, that is a string
(doesn't contain NUL bytes) and fits in a single event packet.
For reliable reception, use the `subscribe` command above.
